Here's what a socially-distanced classroom looks like at KLSD.

This fall classrooms will look different than the way we left them last March. There will be fewer student desks due to spacing desks 6‚Äô apart. Each classroom will average 12 students desks and one to two teachers desks.

Soft objects such as mats, plastic chairs, area rugs, stuffed animals and any fabric-covered items will be at a minimum to facilitate cleaning and disinfecting. Each classroom will be equipped with disinfectant wipes for personal devices and other surfaces. Classrooms without a sink for hand washing will be equipped with an alcohol hand sanitizer dispenser. All classroom ventilation systems will operate non-stop during the occupied hours for maximum air flow.

Our goal is health and safety. Preparing the buildings to be a welcome healthy environment for everyone returning this coming September involves many careful steps and hours of pre-planning. Thank you O&M team!

IMES second graders had a morning that was out of this world! To enhance their study of our solar system, students ‚Äúgraphed‚Äù the varying distances of the planets from the Sun with the help of some toilet paper.

For example, the distance of the Sun to Earth required five squares of toilet paper. However, the distance of the Sun to the dwarf planet Pluto required 100 squares! When they graphed the longer distances, students marked their measurements with the help of Base 10 blocks.

‚ÄúThis created an incredible visual for our learners ‚Ä¶ and it was a lot of fun,‚Äù said Mrs. Dooley, one of the teachers. #KLActiveLearning

Let‚Äôs hear it for Differences Day‚Äîa parent-led SEPTO workshop that helps children understand differences and take a step towards empathy!

Second and fifth grade students spent a session in the school gymnasium, rotating through a series of hands-on activities designed to simulate visual, auditory, speech and motor impairments, as well as learning differences. At one station, they tried on goggles that simulate visual impairment; at another they did puzzles while wearing gloves that evoke fine motor skills challenges. They also tried to carry a lunch tray while navigating in a wheelchair.

Differences Day is unique to the Katonah-Lewisboro School District. Thank you, parents Teryn Kendall and Lori McQuade, chairs of Differences Day 2019, and the many parent volunteers who made this an enriching learning experience. #KLActiveLearning

2nd Place Environmental Science - Grace Mango
3rd Place Animal Science - Nathan Potash
3rd Place Engineering - Alexandra Edelman

The other participating sophomores were: Sophia Gil, Sophie Guo, Amelia Landis, Caroline Lasota, Madeline Panek, Maya Schwartz and Remi Sandell.
